The legal case is aiming to achieve ‘clear and enforceable guidance’ defining what PAs and anaesthesia associates (AAs) ‘can and cannot do’. Last month, the Doctors’ Association UK made a
The post BMA to financially support joint legal challenge against GMC over PAs appeared first on Pulse Today.
articles.title: BMA to financially support joint legal challenge against GMC over PAs

articles.author: Maya Dhillon
articles.description:
Dr Zoe Rog reflects on the Darzi review and looks to the future, pondering what the Government’s next move might be Following the lack of success of the Darzi centre polyclinics 15 years ago, it was with some trepidation that I embarked on reading the recent 163 page investigation of the NHS report by Lord
The post Lord Darzi observed what GPs already knew appeared first on Pulse Today.
articles.title: Lord Darzi observed what GPs already knew

articles.author: Anna Colivicchi
articles.description:
A GP who arranged a fake Covid vaccine appointment so that he could poison his mother’s partner has admitted to attempted murder. Dr Thomas Kwan was charged by police in February following a report of ‘suspected poisoning’ in Newcastle. He went on trial at Newcastle Crown Court last week, but yesterday he pleaded guilty to
The post GP admits attempting murder during fake Covid jab appointment appeared first on Pulse Today.
articles.title: GP admits attempting murder during fake Covid jab appointment

articles.author: Eliza Parr
articles.description:
GP practices will be able to order sub-dermal contraceptive implants directly and claim back the cost from next year.  NHS England has made this change to streamline the process for patients who currently have to go to the pharmacy to pick up the implant themselves and then make a further GP appointment to have it
The post GP practices to order contraceptive implants from January appeared first on Pulse Today.
articles.title: GP practices to order contraceptive implants from January

articles.description: Wes Streeting has told parliament he will 'take seriously' representations from GPs over the impact of employer national insurance contributions announced in the budget last week - as the BMA England GP committee warned hundreds of practices could hand back their contracts over increased costs.
articles.title: Streeting 'aware of pressures' as GPs warn budget risks hundreds of practice closures

articles.description: GP leaders in Wales have voted unanimously to reject a 'beyond insulting' contract offer for the current financial year put forward by the Welsh government - and will now ask the profession to vote in a referendum that could be the first step towards forms of industrial action.
articles.title: Welsh GPs head for referendum after BMA rejects 2024/25 contract offer

articles.description: GP leaders in Wales have voted unanimously to reject a 'beyond insulting' contract offer for the current financial year put forward by the Welsh government - and will now ask the profession to vote in a referendum that could be the first step towards forms of industrial action.
articles.title: BMA Wales rejects GP contract for 2024/25

articles.description: GP leaders will debate calls to ballot the profession on 'more significant industrial action' this month amid fears that the impact of collective action may not be enough to save general practice.
articles.title: LMCs to debate call for 'more significant industrial action' to save general practice

articles.description: A former health minister has been appointed shadow health and social care secretary as new Conservative leader Kemi Badenoch’s shadow front bench takes shape.
articles.title: Conservatives appoint new shadow health and social care secretary

articles.description: GP practices across England are delivering rising numbers of appointments - and those appointments are lasting longer, NHS data confirm.
articles.title: NHS data confirm GP practice appointments are rising and lasting longer

articles.description: GP partners should write to their MPs to demand an urgent rethink after an autumn budget that threatens a 'hammer blow' to practice finances, the BMA has said.
articles.title: GPs urged to write to MPs after budget 'hammer blow' for practices

articles.description: GP practices across England faced ‘chaos' on 4 November after an EMIS IT system outage cut off access to appointment booking systems and left clinicians unable to see patient records.
articles.title: 'Absolute chaos' as GP practices across England hit by EMIS outage

articles.description: The RCGP and NHS Confederation have joined a chorus of demands for urgent assurances that GP practices will be protected from the impact of increased employer national insurance contributions - warning higher costs threaten redundancies and practice closures.
articles.title: Protect GPs from NI hike or risk redundancies and practice closures, say primary care leaders

articles.description: Health ministers are in talks with the Treasury after calls for GP practices to be exempted from a hike in employer national insurance contributions announced in the budget - and the government has promised more detail is to come on how GPs will be affected.
articles.title: Ministers in talks with Treasury after call for GP exemption on NI rise

articles.description: The GPonline team discusses the latest GP workforce figures, GP ARRS jobs, an RCGP plan to improve retention and looks at how the budget will affect practices.
articles.title: Podcast: Is the GP workforce turning a corner? Plus what the budget means for general practice

articles.description: Intense competition for jobs amid the 'absurd' GP unemployment crisis is driving down rates of pay, leaving doctors facing a 'substantial loss of earnings' and driving some out of the NHS, the BMA has warned.
articles.title: GP jobs crisis is driving down rates of pay, BMA warns

articles.description: ICBs are employing GPs on contracts less favourable than the BMA salaried model contract - creating an 'unfair disparity' with terms and conditions for other doctors, the BMA has warned.
articles.title: GPs employed by ICBs face 'unfair contract disparity'

articles.description: More GPs could hand back their contracts after an autumn budget that risks a 'massive impact' on GP practices, accountants have warned.
articles.title: Budget risks 'pushing GPs towards the exit' as practice costs rise

articles.description: The first UK case of the new clade 1b strain of mpox has been confirmed in England but the risk to the population remains low, the UK Health Security Agency (UKHSA) has said.
articles.title: First UK case of mpox clade 1b strain confirmed

articles.description: Day-to-day NHS funding will rise by £22.6bn from 2025/26 and the government will roll out a 'dedicated fund' to upgrade around 200 GP practices, but a 1.2 percentage point hike in employer national insurance contributions and a 6.7% rise in the minimum wage unveiled in the autumn budget could pile extra cost pressures on general practice in the coming financial year.
articles.title: Budget delivers real-terms NHS funding boost but higher costs for GP practices

articles.description: GP practices could be forced to cut services if the government's 30 October budget piles on new unfunded costs through increases to the minimum wage and employer national insurance (NI) contributions, GP leaders have warned.
articles.title: GP fears as budget set to hike minimum wage and NI costs for practices

articles.description: With the first GP recruited through the additional roles reimbursement scheme (ARRS) set to start work within days, GPonline looks at job specifications on offer across England and how they match up with BMA recommendations.
articles.title: What do the emerging ARRS jobs for newly-qualified GPs look like?

articles.description: A newly-qualified GP has signed a contract for an additional roles reimbursement scheme (ARRS) job starting in Wiltshire from next week, GPonline has learned, in what is thought to be the first confirmed GP job created through the scheme.
articles.title: First ARRS GP job confirmed as doctor signs contract with PCN in Wiltshire

articles.description: More than 180,000 consultations took place in July this year under Pharmacy First - a scheme meant to free up 10m GP appointments a year - but analysis reveals significant variation in uptake between ICBs.
articles.title: Pharmacy First uptake rising but huge variation remains across England

articles.description: Chancellor Rachel Reeves has promised the government's 30 October budget will deliver 'new funding' for an extra 2m NHS hospital appointments in a bid to tackle long waits for care that are a major driver of pressure on general practice.
articles.title: Budget will deliver cash to cut NHS waiting list, says chancellor

articles.description: The first GPs could be appointed to additional roles reimbursement scheme (ARRS) roles from the week beginning 28 October after high levels of applications for posts advertised across the country, GPonline can reveal.
articles.title: First ARRS GPs could be appointed within days as applications surge

articles.description: The first GPs could be appointed to additional roles reimbursement scheme (ARRS) roles from next week after high levels of applications for posts advertised across the country, GPonline can reveal.
articles.title: First ARRS GPs could be appointed next week as applications surge

articles.description: Detrimental reforms to pensions and national insurance in the 30 October autumn budget could drive more GP practices out of business, the BMA has warned.
articles.title: Detrimental budget reforms to pensions and NI could force practice closures, warns BMA

articles.description: The government will need to make 'substantial improvements' to primary care during the next five years if it wants to win the next election, Labour's recently-elected GP MP has said.
articles.title: Labour will need to 'substantially improve' primary care to be re-elected, says GP MP

articles.description: Thousands of qualified GPs will be lost to the NHS unless the government rips up its long-term workforce strategy and draws up a 'bold plan to improve GP retention', the RCGP has warned.
articles.title: Rip up NHS workforce plan and create bold GP retention strategy, demands RCGP

articles.description: Detrimental reforms to pensions and national insurance in the 30 October autumn budget could drive more GP practices out of business, the BMA has warned.
articles.title: Detrimental budget reforms to pensions and NI could force practice closures, warns BMA

articles.description: Talking General Practice speaks to  GP Dr Simon Opher, who was elected as the Labour MP for Stroud in Gloucestershire in the general election in July this year.
articles.title: Podcast: Labour’s GP MP Dr Simon Opher on adjusting to life in parliament

articles.description: England's GP workforce has risen to a five-year high despite an ongoing jobs crisis that has left thousands of GPs struggling to find work, official data show.
articles.title: GP workforce hits five-year high despite ongoing jobs crisis

articles.description: The RCGP has said it will ‘support’ any GP registrars considering deliberately failing their exams to stay in employment.
articles.title: RCGP offers help to GPs struggling to find work after reports of deliberate exam failures

articles.description: Half of remedial statements sent to doctors affected by age discrimination under the NHS pension scheme contain errors, expert accountants have warned.
articles.title: Half of NHS pension statements to fix age discrimination 'contain errors'

articles.description: Patients have praised ‘amazing’ GP practice staff after an ‘emergency situation’ forced a surgery to cancel appointments and close for one afternoon.
articles.title: Man charged after 'emergency situation' in GP practice waiting room

articles.description: Doctors on the Isle of Man - including salaried GPs - will be balloted over industrial action for the first time ever, the BMA has announced.
articles.title: BMA to ballot Isle of Man doctors over industrial action

articles.description: The government should investigate the potential merits of capping the number of appointments a GP can carry out per day, a Labour MP has said.

articles.description: GPs in Wales have called for a 'fairer portion of NHS funding' after a report found significant pressure on general practice amid practice closures, staff shortages and the impact of long hospital waiting lists.

articles.description: Contracts for GP ARRS jobs should cap daily appointments at the BMA-recommended safe limit and offer salaries at least £10,000 higher than the level proposed by NHS England, BMA guidance warns.

articles.description: Thousands of GPs are still struggling to find work - and more practice funding could 'bring back the family doctor overnight', a leading GP has said.

articles.description: A public consultation launched today by the government will shape a programme of reform that it says will be the 'biggest reimagining of the NHS' in its 76-year history.

articles.description: Around 13m hormone replacement therapy (HRT) items were prescribed in England in 2023/24, a 22% increase since 2022/23, according to the latest NHS figures.

articles.description: An NHS England director has said ICBs are using money earmarked for primary care to plug hospital deficits - and that she would 'love to reinstate' GP fellowships, but that the health service simply can't afford to in the current financial climate.

articles.description: Updated NICE guidance on patients at risk of falls could shift responsibility for home hazard assessments from healthcare professionals to occupational therapists, as part of the first major update to the advice in more than a decade.

articles.description: Disparities in fitness to practise referrals between ethnic minority and white doctors could be eradicated by 2026, the GMC has said - but the regulator warned inequality remains 'embedded in medicine' and called for cultural change.

articles.description: The CQC plans to step up inspections and simplify its assessment process after a report confirmed serious failings at the watchdog - as the government launched a further review that could call its future into doubt.

articles.description: Creating GP jobs through the additional roles reimbursement scheme (ARRS) was a useful emergency solution but may not be the way to expand GP capacity 'forever', a senior NHS England official has suggested.

articles.description: Physician associates will be invited to register with the GMC from 16 December - but won't be legally required to do so for a further two years, the regulator has said.

articles.description: BMA leaders have set out terms for a once-in-a-generation overhaul of the GP contract that could take effect from 2028.

articles.description: BMA GP leaders have called on the government to increase core general practice funding per patient by £40 per year - 11p per day - from 2025/26 as a first step towards ending collective action.

articles.description:
A new World Health Organization (WHO) study published today in eBioMedicine names 17 pathogens that regularly cause diseases in communities as top priorities for new vaccine development. The WHO study is the first global effort to systematically prioritize endemic pathogens based on criteria that included regional disease burden, antimicrobial resistance risk and socioeconomic impact. 
The study reconfirms longstanding priorities for vaccine research and development (R&D), including for HIV, malaria, and tuberculosis – three diseases that collectively take nearly 2.5 million lives each year. 
The study also identifies pathogens such as Group A streptococcus and Klebsiella pneumoniae as top disease control priorities in all regions, highlighting the urgency to develop new vaccines for patho…
articles.title: WHO study lists top endemic pathogens for which new vaccines are urgently needed

articles.description:
We the leaders of 15 United Nations and humanitarian organizations urge, yet again, all parties fighting in Gaza to protect civilians, and call on the State of Israel to cease its assault on Gaza and on the humanitarians trying to help. 
The situation unfolding in North Gaza is apocalyptic. The area has been under siege for almost a month, denied basic aid and life-saving supplies while bombardment and other attacks continue. Just in the past few days, hundreds of Palestinians have been killed, most of them women and children, and thousands have once again been forcibly displaced. 
Hospitals have been almost entirely cut off from supplies and have come under attack, killing patients, destroying vital equipment, and disrupting life-saving services. Health workers and patients have been take…
articles.title: Statement by Principals of the Inter-Agency Standing Committee – Stop the assault on Palestinians in Gaza and on those trying to help them

articles.description:
A third phase of the polio vaccination campaign is set to begin tomorrow in part of the northern Gaza Strip after being postponed from 23 October 2024 due to lack of access and assured, comprehensive humanitarian pauses, intense bombardment, and mass evacuation orders. These conditions made it impossible for families to safely bring their children for vaccination and to organize campaign activities.  

"The humanitarian pause necessary to conduct the campaign has been assured; however, the area of the pause has been substantially reduced compared to the first round of vaccination in northern Gaza, conducted in September 2024. It is now limited to just Gaza City. Though in the past few weeks, at least 100 000 people have been forced to evacuate from North Gaza towards Gaza City for safety, …
articles.title: Polio vaccination campaign to resume in northern Gaza

articles.description:
As part of ongoing efforts to enhance quality-assured testing options, the World Health Organization (WHO) has listed two additional mpox in vitro diagnostics under its Emergency Use Listing (EUL) procedure. WHO’s EUL is based on the review of quality, safety and performance data in compliance with international standards while addressing the specific needs of low- and middle-income countries (LMICs).
Polymerase Chain Reaction (PCR) testing, which detects viral DNA, is considered the gold standard for diagnosing mpox infection.
WHO listed the Xpert Mpox, a real-time PCR test manufactured by Cepheid under its EUL procedure, on 25 October. This test is designed for use on compatible GeneXpert systems. The Xpert Mpox test is easy to operate and delivers results in under 40 minutes. Once the c…
articles.title: WHO lists additional mpox diagnostic tests for emergency use

articles.description:
In October 2024, WHO and partners, in collaboration with Member States, activated the Global Health Emergency Corps (GHEC) for the first time to provide support to countries facing mpox outbreaks.
GHEC is a grouping of professionals with the objective of strengthening the response to health emergencies, and a collaboration platform for countries and health emergency networks. It supports countries on their health emergency workforce, the surge deployment of experts and the networking of technical leaders. GHEC was established by WHO in 2023 after the response to the COVID-19 pandemic revealed the need to streamline efforts of existing networks to ensure better-coordinated support to countries. 
“WHO and partners are supporting the government of the Democratic Republic of the Congo and othe…
articles.title: WHO and partners activate Global Health Emergency Corps for the first time in response to mpox outbreak

articles.description:
The World Health Organization (WHO) today published a new report on tuberculosis revealing that approximately 8.2 million people were newly diagnosed with TB in 2023 – the highest number recorded since WHO began global TB monitoring in 1995. This represents a notable increase from 7.5 million reported in 2022, placing TB again as the leading infectious disease killer in 2023, surpassing COVID-19. 
WHO’s Global Tuberculosis Report 2024 highlights mixed progress in the global fight against TB, with persistent challenges such as significant underfunding. While the number of TB-related deaths decreased from 1.32 million in 2022 to 1.25 million in 2023, the total number of people falling ill with TB rose slightly to an estimated 10.8 million in 2023. 
With the disease disproportionately affecti…
articles.title: Tuberculosis resurges as top infectious disease killer

articles.description:
Due to the escalating violence, intense bombardment, mass displacement orders, and lack of assured humanitarian pauses across most of northern Gaza, the Polio Technical Committee for Gaza, including the Palestinian Ministry of Health, World Health Organization (WHO), United Nations Children’s Fund (UNICEF), the United Nations Relief and Works Agency for Palestine Refugees (UNRWA) and partners have been compelled to postpone the third phase of the polio vaccination campaign, which was set to begin today. This final phase of the ongoing campaign aimed to vaccinate 119 279 children across northern Gaza.
The current conditions, including ongoing attacks on civilian infrastructure continue to jeopardize people’s safety and movement in northern Gaza, making it impossible for families to safely b…
articles.title: Intense bombardments, mass displacements and lack of access in northern Gaza force the postponement of polio vaccination campaign

articles.description:
On 21 October, 14 patients and 10 caregivers were transferred from Kamal Adwan in North Gaza to Al-Shifa Hospital in Gaza City during a high-risk, WHO-led joint mission, amid intense hostilities and access restrictions. Despite an initial agreement, the delivery of critical medical supplies, blood, and fuel – resources essential for keeping Kamal Adwan and Al-Awda hospitals operational – was denied just a few hours before the mission began on 20 October. 

The mission lasted two days, with the team facing delays at successive checkpoints, and during extensive security screenings. The team was forced to stay overnight at Kamal Adwan Hospital, as they were not cleared to proceed to Al-Shifa hospital due to active conflict in the area. Heavy bombardment continued near the hospital throughout …
articles.title: Patients transferred, critical supplies denied as high-risk, on WHO-led joint mission in northern Gaza amid intense hostilities

articles.description:
The World Health Organization (WHO) and the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia announced a new milestone digital health collaboration today to expand the Hajj health card initiative to support the roughly 3 million pilgrims who undertake the holy pilgrimage every year.
The Hajj health card, built on the WHO Global Digital Health Certification Network’s public key infrastructure, summarizes critical health information, such as medication needs, allergies, immunization status and pre-existing conditions. The card gives individuals agency over their own health information when they travel to Saudi Arabia so that they can provide authorized health providers access to accurate, up-to-date patient summary information and obtain personalized quality care. 
“Today marks a notable progress in WHO’s support to…
articles.title: WHO global network expands digital health certification for Hajj pilgrims

articles.description: The World Health Organization (WHO) has certified Egypt as malaria-free, marking a significant public health milestone for a country with more than 100 million inhabitants. The achievement follows a nearly 100-year effort by the Egyptian government and people to end a disease that has been present in the country since ancient times.
articles.title: Egypt is certified malaria-free by WHO

articles.description:
On 16 October, the Ministry of Public Health of Lebanon confirmed a cholera case, highlighting the escalating health risks amidst ongoing conflict. The case was identified in Akkar governorate in the north of the country, marking the first case since the October 2022-June 2023 outbreak was declared over. Authorities are investigating the extent of the disease’s spread, gathering samples from the patient’s contacts, and assessing potential water contamination. 
“WHO has been sounding the alarm on the risk of emerging infectious diseases like cholera resurfacing in Lebanon as a result of poor water and sanitation conditions and the impact of the current conflict.” said Dr Abdinasir Abubakar, WHO Representative in Lebanon. “Our immediate focus now is to enhance surveillance and water sanitati…
articles.title: WHO in Lebanon working to stop cholera spread amid conflict

articles.description:
Geneva 17 October 2024 – This afternoon, His Excellency Mr Jérôme Bonnafont, Permanent Representative of France to the United Nations in Geneva, and WHO Director-General Dr Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus met in the WHO headquarters for the signing of seven contribution agreements.

The contribution totalling €24 million comes through the Ministry of Europe & Foreign Affairs. It fits in the France–WHO Framework Agreement for 2020 to 2025, which provides both a strategic framework for engagement, aligned with WHO priorities, while providing legal, administrative and financial instruments for operationalizing collaboration.
This latest contribution includes a generous €4.5 million in fully flexible voluntary funds for the Core Voluntary Contributions Account (CVCA).
Additionally, France will supp…
articles.title: Signing ceremony for contribution agreements between WHO and France

articles.description:
Parliamentarians from across the globe gathered at the UNITE Global Summit in Berlin to sign a statement in support of the World Health Organization Pandemic Agreement. The statement, signed by the President of UNITE, members of its board, and parliamentarians around the world, marks a significant commitment from parliamentarians to strengthen pandemic preparedness, response, and equitable access to health. 
“Parliamentarians are the voice of the people and have a crucial responsibility in safeguarding public health,” said Ricardo Baptista Leite, President of UNITE. “The WHO Pandemic Agreement represents a historic opportunity to prevent pandemics and strengthen our global preparedness and response capabilities. By signing this statement, we are not only showing our support for the agreeme…
articles.title: Parliamentarians Unite in Berlin to Sign Global Statement Supporting the WHO Pandemic Agreement

articles.description:
Since the escalation of hostilities between Israel and Lebanon on 17 September 2024, WHO has verified 23 attacks on health care in Lebanon that have led to 72 deaths and 43 injuries among health workers and patients. Fifteen incidents impacted health facilities, while 13 impacted health transport. Hospitals in Lebanon are already under massive strain as they strive to sustain essential health services while dealing with an unprecedented influx of injured people. Understaffed and under-resourced, the health system has been struggling to maintain uninterrupted services to all those in need with supplies being depleted and health workers exhausted.
Increasing conflict, intense bombardment and insecurity are forcing a growing number of health facilities to shut down, particularly in the south.…
articles.title: Attacks on hospitals and health workers jeopardize provision of health in Lebanon

articles.description:
In a powerful demonstration of high-level support, the World Health Organization (WHO) today received nearly US$ 700 million in new funding commitments from European countries, foundations and others, and another US$ 300 million in reaffirmed commitments.
Announced at the WHO Investment Round Signature Event at the World Health Summit in Berlin hosted by Germany, France, and Norway, the commitments highlighted the urgent need for investments in the Organization’s mission to improve health outcomes worldwide. 
The world’s global health strategy, WHO's Fourteenth General Programme of Work 2025-2028, was approved by WHO’s 194 Member States at the World Health Assembly in May. The Organization’s first ever Investment Round, also launched at the Assembly, aims to ensure that WHO has the predict…
articles.title: US$ 1 billion in new and reaffirmed funding commitments announced for WHO’s ongoing Investment Round

articles.description:
The WHO Youth Council has launched its first Youth Declaration on Creating Healthy Societies, with a range of calls to action informed and developed by young people from around the world and geared towards empowering youth to play a central role in creating healthier and safer societies for all.
"The WHO Youth Council is proud to be issuing its first Youth Declaration on Creating Healthy Societies," said Kate Ndocko, WHO Youth Council member. "This Declaration represents our collective commitment and priorities to help communities, especially youth, at local, regional and global levels, to be healthier and more resilient in the face of the many health challenges the world faces today as well as the ones ahead."
The Declaration was launched today during the World Health Summit taking place …
articles.title: WHO Youth Council releases bold call for a healthier world

articles.description:
The second round of an emergency polio vaccination campaign is scheduled to start on 14 October 2024 in Gaza, to vaccinate an estimated 591 700 children under ten years of age with a second dose of the novel oral polio vaccine type 2 (nOPV2) vaccine.
This follows a first round, which was successfully implemented from 1-12 September 2024 and vaccinated 559 161 children, or an estimated 95% of eligible children at governorate level, according to independently conducted post-campaign monitoring. As with the first round, the second round will have three phases, each involving three campaign days and one catch-up day.
A minimum of two doses of nOPV2 are needed to interrupt poliovirus transmission. However, this will only be achieved if at least 90% of all children are vaccinated in all communit…
articles.title: Second round of polio vaccination in the Gaza Strip aims to vaccinate over half a million children

articles.description:
A new report by the World Health Organization (WHO) finds that vaccines against 24 pathogens could reduce the number of antibiotics needed by 22% or 2.5 billion defined daily doses globally every year, supporting worldwide efforts to address antimicrobial resistance (AMR). While some of these vaccines are already available but underused, others would need to be developed and brought to the market as soon as possible.
AMR occurs when bacteria, viruses, fungi, and parasites no longer respond to antimicrobial medicines, making people sicker and increasing the risk of illness, death and the spread of infections that are difficult to treat. AMR is driven largely by the misuse and overuse of antimicrobials, yet, at the same time, many people around the world do not have access to essential antim…
articles.title: Better use of vaccines could reduce antibiotic use by 2.5 billion doses annually, says WHO

articles.description:
The World Health Organization (WHO) and the Kingdom of the Netherlands have renewed their strategic partnership in addressing the growing impacts of climate change on global health.
The Netherlands is providing a new allocation of €500 000 for 2024 to WHO, reinforcing its commitment to climate resilience and sustainable healthcare systems worldwide. This allocation supports WHO’s ongoing efforts to strengthen the Alliance for Transformative Action on Climate and Health Secretariat and advance climate change and health programmes globally.
This contribution builds on the partnership established in 2023 between the Netherlands and WHO to collaborate on climate change and health. Together, they have supported African, Asian and Eastern Mediterranean countries in advancing the implementation o…
articles.title: WHO and the Netherlands renew their partnership on climate change and health
